metadata.titleEn: The SRTM digital elevation model of the Tibetan Plateau (2000)
metadata.description:
This data set is a digital elevation model of the Tibetan Plateau and can be used to assist in analysis and research of basic geographic information for the Tibetan Plateau.
The raw data were the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) data, which were provided by Global Land Cover Network (GLCN), and the raw data were framing data , using the WGS84 coordinate system, including latitude and longitude, with a spatial resolution of 3″. After the mosaic processing, the Nodata (null data) generated in the mosaic process were interpolated and filled. After filling, the projection conversion process was performed to generate data as Albers equal area conical projection. After the conversion projection, the spatial resolution of the data was 90 m. Finally, the boundary of the Tibetan Plateau was used for cutting to obtain DEM data.
This data table has two fields.
Field 1: value
Data type: long integer 
Interpretation: altitude elevation 
Unit: m 
Field 2: count 
Data type: long integer 
Interpretation: The number of map spots corresponding to the altitude elevation
Data accuracy: spatial resolution: 90 m

background: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission produced the most complete, highest-resolution digital elevation model of the Earth. The project was a joint endeavor of NASA, the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency, and the German and Italian Space Agencies and flew in February 2000. At the foundation of modern geosciences, quite literally, is knowledge of the shape of the Earth’s surface. Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality: some with astounding accuracy, some far less adequate. It has proven exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means. The emergence, in the 1990s, of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry placed the possibility of efficiently and affordably creating a global digital elevation model within the grasp of spacefaring nations. Interferometric SAR, or InSAR, makes use of phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio (typically 0.0002) to measure topography.
research objective: The SRTM objective was to acquire a digital elevation model of all land between about 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude, about 80% of Earth’s land surface. The operational goal of C radar was to generate contiguous mapping coverage as called for by the mission objectives. X radar was included as an experimental demonstration. As it did not employ ScanSAR, the X band radar had a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) than the C band system. The key to successful acquisition of a data set suitable for automated production is to remove the variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations and to measure the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects accurately at all times during data acquisition.
challenges: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality: some with astounding accuracy, some far less adequate. Furthermore, the global coverage has been uneven. It has proven exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means. Optical stereo mapping systems suffer from poor control and matching difficulties in areas of low contrast and from persistent cloud cover in many important areas of the world.
methods: Following the launch, the first 12 hours of flight were taken up by on-orbit checkout (OOCO), during which the payload bay doors were opened, the SRTM system was activated and checked, and the orbiter was maneuvered to the mapping attitude. Mapping continued for 149 orbits (222.4 hours). Data were acquired at the rate of 180 megabits per second (Mbps) (C radar) and at 90 Mbps (X radar). Selected snapshots of data necessary for near-real-time performance assessment were down linked via the shuttle Ku band and NASA’s tracking and data relay system (TDRS) link to JPL in Pasadena and to the Payload Operations Control Center (POCC) in Houston.
dataset: A total of 765 data takes were executed. Of these, 399 were C radar only, 1 was X radar only, and 365 were simultaneous C and X radar. The volume of data produced by SRTM, 12.3 Tb (8.6 Tb by C radar, 3.7 Tb by X radar), compares to the capacity of the Library of Congress.

Verification.Question: Does the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) use synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry as a data collection method?
Is the data acquired from SRTM intended to cover about 80% of Earth's land surface?

Disjunctive.Question: Are the challenges in producing a global digital elevation model primarily due to conventional topographic mapping technologies, optical stereo mapping systems, or persistent cloud cover?
Disjunctive.Answer: conventional topographic mapping technologies and optical stereo mapping systems

Disjunctive.Question: Was the data acquisition rate during the mission higher for C radar or X radar?

Concept Completion.Question: What method was used to acquire the digital elevation model data of the Earth's surface?
Where was the data from the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission processed and assessed in near-real time?
What challenge is associated with conventional topographic mapping technologies?

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a data collection method used to generate a digital elevation model of a large geographic region like the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used is the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM), which utilized synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry to acquire digital elevation models by measuring phase differences from radar images.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in creating a consistent global digital elevation model?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is that conventional topographic mapping technologies often produce maps of uneven quality, and it is difficult and expensive to achieve a consistent scale and resolution globally with conventional mapping methods.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the primary attributes and resolution characteristics of digital elevation models used in topographic mapping?
Feature Specification.Answer: 90m spatial resolution, long integer data types for elevation in meters, count of image patches corresponding to elevations

Feature Specification.Question: What challenges are encountered in ensuring the consistency and quality of global digital elevation models?
Feature Specification.Answer: uneven quality, consistent scale and resolution, poor control, matching difficulties in areas of low contrast

Feature Specification.Question: What are the features of radar systems used in data collection for digital elevation models?
Feature Specification.Answer: C radar, X radar, contiguous mapping coverage, slightly higher resolution, better signal-to-noise ratio, 180 Mbps for C radar, 90 Mbps for X radar

Quantification.Question: How many orbits were completed during the data collection phase of the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission?
What is the total volume of data produced by the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission in terabytes?
How many data takes executed only involved the C radar system?

Definition.Question: What is the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) and how is it significant in creating digital elevation models?
Definition.Answer: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) was a project aimed at acquiring a digital elevation model of all land between about 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude, covering approximately 80% of Earth’s land surface. It was a joint endeavor of NASA, the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency, and the German and Italian Space Agencies. The mission utilized synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry to efficiently and affordably create a global digital elevation model, making use of phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images.

Definition.Question: What are some challenges associated with conventional topographic mapping technologies?
Definition.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality, with some being highly accurate and others less so. One of the challenges is achieving global coverage with consistent scale and resolution, which has been difficult and expensive by traditional means. Optical stereo mapping systems also face issues such as poor control and matching difficulties in areas of low contrast and persistent cloud cover.

Definition.Question: How does interferometric synthetic aperture radar (InSAR) contribute to topographic mapping?
Definition.Answer: Interferometric synthetic aperture radar (InSAR) contributes to topographic mapping by using phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio to measure topography. This method allows for efficient and affordable creation of digital elevation models, which is especially advantageous for generating global maps with consistent scale and resolution.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method of the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) using Interferometric SAR compare to conventional topographic mapping technologies in terms of global coverage and resolution consistency?
Comparison.Answer: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) using Interferometric SAR provided a more consistent scale and resolution for a global digital elevation model compared to conventional topographic mapping technologies, which often resulted in uneven quality and coverage.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges faced by conventional topographic mapping technologies differ from those encountered by the SRTM in acquiring a global digital elevation model?
Comparison.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies faced challenges such as uneven quality and global coverage, while SRTM encountered difficulties related to pass-to-pass variability, decorrelation, and the need for accurate measurement of systematic effects during data acquisition.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data volume and acquisition rates between C radar and X radar data collection methods used during the SRTM, and how do these differences impact the overall dataset produced?
Comparison.Answer: During the SRTM, data were acquired at 180 Mbps for C radar and 90 Mbps for X radar, resulting in a total data volume of 12.3 Tb, with 8.6 Tb from C radar and 3.7 Tb from X radar. These differences in data volume and acquisition rates influenced the overall dataset by providing a larger dataset from C radar, which was the primary radar system used.

Interpretation.Question: What can the use of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry in data collection reveal about the feasibility of creating global digital elevation models?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of SAR interferometry allows for efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model by utilizing phase-difference measurements from two radar images. This method overcomes the challenges and costs associated with conventional topographic mapping technologies, which often result in uneven quality and inconsistent global coverage.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for the challenges in achieving consistent scale and resolution in global digital elevation models through conventional topographic mapping methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality, with some having astounding accuracy and others being far less adequate. Global coverage has been uneven, and it has been exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means. Optical stereo mapping systems, for instance, suffer from poor control and matching difficulties in areas of low contrast and persistent cloud cover in many important regions of the world.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why was synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry considered a viable solution for creating a global digital elevation model?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The emergence of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry in the 1990s made it possible to efficiently and affordably create a global digital elevation model. Interferometric SAR, or InSAR, uses phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio to measure topography. This method presented an opportunity for spacefaring nations to overcome the challenges and limitations of conventional topographic mapping technologies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contributed to the decision to include both C radar and X radar in the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission, and how did they impact data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The objective of the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission was to acquire a digital elevation model of Earth's land surface between about 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude. The C radar aimed to generate contiguous mapping coverage, while the X radar was included as an experimental demonstration due to its slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) compared to the C band system. This dual-radar approach allowed for a more comprehensive data collection, addressing the need for both operational mapping and experimental validation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry for digital elevation model generation in terms of data accuracy and coverage?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry can efficiently and affordably create a global digital elevation model with consistent scale and resolution, overcoming challenges related to the uneven quality and coverage of conventional topographic mapping technologies.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations affect the successful acquisition of a digital elevation model dataset during data collection?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations could negatively impact the successful acquisition of a digital elevation model dataset. Therefore, removing this variability and accurately measuring the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects are crucial for automated production.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of the global coverage challenges faced by conventional topographic mapping technologies on the development of new data collection methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The challenges of uneven global coverage and variable quality in conventional topographic mapping technologies have necessitated the development of new data collection methods like SAR interferometry, which offer more consistent and comprehensive elevation data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of acquiring a digital elevation model for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau using advanced radar technologies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to facilitate foundational geographic information analysis for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau region and to create a consistent and high-resolution digital elevation model of the Earth's surface, using synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry to efficiently and affordably map topography.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address the variability and decorrelation issues during the data acquisition process for topographic mapping missions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to address these issues to ensure the successful acquisition of a dataset suitable for automated production. Accurate measurement of the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects at all times during data acquisition are crucial to removing variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of achieving consistent scale and resolution in global digital elevation models for geoscientific research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Achieving consistent scale and resolution in global digital elevation models is significant for geoscientific research because it overcomes the challenges of uneven quality and coverage in conventional topographic mapping technologies, allowing for more reliable and comprehensive analysis of the Earth's surface.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to fill Nodata values during the digital elevation model creation process for regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Interpolation techniques are used to fill Nodata values created during the mosaicking process of the digital elevation model for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the data acquired by the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission processed to achieve the desired projection and resolution for geographic analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data from the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission is processed by performing a projection conversion to Albers equal-area conic projection after filling Nodata values, resulting in a spatial resolution of 90 meters.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What systematic approaches are necessary to ensure the accuracy of data acquisition in creating a digital elevation model covering diverse terrain?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure accuracy, it is crucial to remove variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations, and measure the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects accurately during data acquisition.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the efficient and affordable creation of global digital elevation models in recent years?
Enablement.Answer: The emergence of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry in the 1990s enabled the efficient and affordable creation of global digital elevation models. Interferometric SAR, or InSAR, uses phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio to measure topography.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods helped overcome the challenges of conventional topographic mapping technologies in producing a consistent global map set?
Enablement.Answer: The data collection method of using interferometric SAR (InSAR) during the SRTM mission helped overcome challenges of conventional topographic mapping technologies. InSAR allowed for the production of a global digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution, by leveraging the phase-difference measurements from radar images.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to produce a global digital elevation model with consistent scale and resolution using conventional topographic mapping technologies?
Expectation.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality, with some having astounding accuracy and others being far less adequate. Furthermore, the global coverage has been uneven, making it exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means.

Expectation.Question: Why is it expected that the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) can generate a more complete digital elevation model compared to traditional mapping techniques?
Expectation.Answer: The emergence of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry, specifically Interferometric SAR (InSAR), allowed for the efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model. This method uses phase-difference measurements from two radar images to measure topography, providing a more consistent and high-resolution model compared to conventional means.

Expectation.Question: Why would a dataset collected through radar methods have an anticipated higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio compared to others?
Expectation.Answer: In the SRTM, the X band radar was included as an experimental demonstration and had a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) than the C band system. This was because the X band radar did not employ ScanSAR, allowing for improved data quality.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the challenges faced in producing a global digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges in producing a global digital elevation model include the uneven quality of maps produced by conventional topographic mapping technologies and the difficulty and expense involved in achieving consistent scale and resolution globally. Additionally, optical stereo mapping systems face issues with poor control and matching difficulties in low contrast areas and persistent cloud cover in many regions.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the effectiveness of the data collection methods used by the SRTM in terms of achieving its research objectives?
Judgmental.Answer: The SRTM employed synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry for data collection, which was crucial for efficiently and affordably creating a global digital elevation model. The mission's objective was to acquire a model of all land between 60° north and 56° south latitude, covering about 80% of Earth's land surface. The effectiveness of the data collection methods is demonstrated by the successful acquisition of a comprehensive dataset, despite the inherent challenges of variability and decorrelation in pass-to-pass observations.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential benefits or limitations of using SAR interferometry as a data collection technique for global mapping projects?
Judgmental.Answer: SAR interferometry, or InSAR, offers the potential benefit of enabling spacefaring nations to create a global digital elevation model efficiently and affordably. This technique leverages phase-difference measurements from radar images to measure topography, which can overcome many challenges faced by conventional mapping technologies. However, the limitations could include the need for precise measurement of the interferometer baseline and systematic effects during data acquisition to ensure the dataset's suitability for automated production.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how interferometric SAR technology can effectively create a consistent global digital elevation model.
Assertion.Answer: Interferometric SAR, or InSAR, makes use of phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio to measure topography. This method allows for efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure why creating a digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution globally is so challenging using conventional methods.
Assertion.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality, and global coverage has been uneven. It has been difficult and expensive to produce a global map set of consistent scale and resolution because optical stereo mapping systems suffer from poor control, matching difficulties in low contrast areas, and issues with persistent cloud cover in many important areas.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how the data from the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission was organized and managed given its large volume.
Assertion.Answer: A total of 765 data takes were executed, resulting in a data volume of 12.3 Tb. Data acquired at high rates were downlinked via the shuttle Ku band and NASA’s tracking and data relay system to JPL in Pasadena and to the Payload Operations Control Center in Houston for near-real-time performance assessment.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in collecting topographic data and how synthetic aperture radar interferometry addresses these issues.
Request/Directive.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality and global coverage has been uneven. It is difficult and expensive to produce a global digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means. Optical stereo mapping systems face challenges such as poor control and matching difficulties in areas of low contrast and persistent cloud cover. The emergence of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry, or InSAR, addresses these issues by using phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images to measure topography efficiently and affordably.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used in acquiring digital elevation models during the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission.
Request/Directive.Answer: During the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission, data were acquired at the rate of 180 Mbps using C radar and at 90 Mbps using X radar. The mission executed 765 data takes, with 399 using C radar only, 1 using X radar only, and 365 using both C and X radar simultaneously. Data snapshots necessary for near-real-time performance assessment were downlinked via the shuttle Ku band and NASA’s tracking and data relay system to JPL in Pasadena and the Payload Operations Control Center in Houston.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential methods for improving the resolution and consistency of digital elevation models derived from radar data.
Request/Directive.Answer: The key to successful acquisition of a data set suitable for automated production is to remove variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations and accurately measure the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects during data acquisition. The X band radar, although experimental, had a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio than the C band system, indicating that employing higher resolution radar systems and improving signal processing techniques could improve the resolution and consistency of digital elevation models.
